title: Hugo Grüters
text:
Hugo Grüters (8 October 1851 in <a href="Uerdingen">Uerdingen</a> – 19 August 1928 in <a href="Leukerbad">Leukerbad</a>) was a German conductor.
Life and career.
Grüters was born on 8 October 1851 in Uerdingen. His father was an organist and choirmaster and the first teacher of his son. In 1867 Grüters began to study at the <a href="Cologne%20Conservatory">Cologne Conservatory</a> with <a href="Isidor%20Seiss">Isidor Seiss</a> (piano), <a href="Otto%20von%20K%C3%B6nigsl%C3%B6w">Otto von Königslöw</a> (violin), Franz Weber (organ), <a href="Friedrich%20Gernsheim">Friedrich Gernsheim</a> and <a href="Ernst%20Rudorff">Ernst Rudorff</a> (counterpoint) and <a href="Ferdinand%20Hiller">Ferdinand Hiller</a> (composition).
In 1884 Grüters started as Royal Director of Music in <a href="Duisburg">Duisburg</a> and fourteen years later he became Music Director in Bonn. There he was responsible for the Beethoven Festival, the Handel Festival 1900, and the Schumann Festival.
The famous violinist <a href="Joseph%20Joachim">Joseph Joachim</a> was his friend and <a href="Adolf%20Busch">Adolf Busch</a> his most famous composition student.
